column1: Between 1 January 2019 and 31 December 2019, will an armed group from Yemen engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Yemen?
column6: ['Society', 'Security and Conflict']
column11: The EWP is asking forecasters to help provide early risk assessments to policy makers, NGOs, and other international actors about the systematic killing of civilians resulting in mass fatalities (Early Warning Project). This question is part of a series of quarterly questions (Good Judgment Inc). It will be suspended on 31 March 2019 and will be resolved in January 2020 after EWP assesses the situation in Yemen from January 2019 to December 2019. Armed groups include but are not limited to state security forces, rebel armies, and other militias. Campaigns that systematically kill civilians include, but are not limited to, policies which intentionally kill civilians en masse (e.g., military strategies that intentionally target civilians, mass execution of a specific group) and policies that knowingly result in widespread death (e.g., mass starvation, confiscation of health care supplies, forced relocation). In general, unrelated executions of individuals or the accidental killing of civilians in war will not be considered a campaign to systematically kill civilians. If an armed group is engaged in multiple campaigns that systematically kill civilians (e.g., in different geographic areas, or targeted against separate civilian groups) those fatalities will be counted separately and the question will only resolve as yes if 1,000 civilian fatalities occur in one or more campaigns. See The Early Warning Project for examples. See GJ’s FAQ on forecasting questions like this. Confused? Check our FAQ or ask us for help.

column6: Yemen has been torn apart by conflict since 2014, when Houthi rebels, allied with army loyal to former President Ali Abdullah Saleh, captured large expanses of the country, including the capital, Sana'a. A coalition of Arab countries assembled by Saudi Arabia launched an air campaign against the rebels in March 2015 to try to restore the internationally recognised government of President Abd-Rabbu Mansour Hadi to power. Parties on both sides of the conflict have violated international humanitarian law. So far, there have been approximately 67,654 to 90,100 deaths overall in Yemen (Human Rights Watch, 2019) of which approximately 6,872 to 7,000+ civilians (HRW).

I consider it to be very unlikely that 1.000 or more civilians will be systematically killed in Yemen by the end of 2019. Starting with the baseline figures, regarding the EWP report, it is important to take into account that mass killing as such is a rare event. Statistically, one or two countries per year face mass killing. Yemen ranks 6th highest among 162 countries and is considered as a country with 'consistently high-risk'. However, experience shows that facing significant risks doesn't automatically mean gives an assumption about the occurrence of mass killing. According to EWP, top-risk countries that were high in the ranking of risk, have yet to experience a mass killing onset. Another important detail is that the EWP concept of mass killing is specifically addressing internal threats and excluding foreign countries. Hence, as we are not including killings perpetrated by foreign countries' armies into the definition, the chances of mass killing to happen are decreasing even more just because of the complexity of the definition. In addition, I give a 5% likelihood that the mass killing will occur in Yemen during 2019. Despite the arguments expressed before, there are also a lot of uncertainties regarding Yemen. Therefore, knowing that Yemen is very high in the EWP risk assessment, there is still a slight possibility that mass killing can happen in Yemen.

Here are my thoughts on a base rate. Looking at the data visualisation from this source (https://ourworldindata.org/war-and-peace) conflicts in the 2010's in general does not on average have more than 1000 deaths. Concluding on this, it is a rare an exceedingly rare thing for a conflict to lead to 1000 or more deaths. I haven't calculated the baserate, but I would guesstimate the baserate around 5-10% or ≈ 7%. I will use this as my starting point.
No change to previous forecast. Information has not shown significant changes in the situation.

Base line: Yemen had never had a mass killing according to EWP. But we could look to other countries that had mass killing before. F.ex. Arab countries that went through Arab Spring protests that resulted that at some point led to mass killings (Algeria, Egypt, Libya, Sudan, Syria). But it did not happen in other Arab Countries after the Arab Spring - Tunisia, Bahrain, Morocco, Jordan, Lebanon, Oman, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Yemen. So 4 out of 14 countries had a mass killing. So the base line is roughly 28,5 % that their will occur a mass killing in Yemen. Note: mass killings as reported in EWP country data.

Forecast: Assess a 10% risk of one or more campaigns killing 1000 civilians during the 365-day period from 1JAN19 to 31DEC19. Existing ceasefire has removed 3 months of “fighting and should remain in place for another month, at least. EWP definition makes reaching 1000 during a subsequent campaign by either side difficult even with the conflicts avg of 3 civilian deaths per day during 5-year conflict.
No major changes since the last forecast update.

The Yemeni civil war has been going on for 4 years now. Looking over the list of modern middle eastern conflicts, they mostly seem to either end after 1-2 years or drag on for 8 years or more. Since the war hasn't been won quickly, I'll venture a 90% chance the war will drag on beyond this year.

Understanding the political nature of the Yemen conflict, the motives of all involved parties and the environment which amplifies the numbers of casualties are key to assess the possibility for a systematic killing of civilians. Therefore, this analysis will focus first on the overall situation in order to estimate the development in the near future.

According to information received by the UN Human Rights Office, at least 110 airstrikes were carried out in Al Hodeidah, Sa’ada and San’a between 31 October and 6 November, with further intensification since then.

Deconstruction and assessing the question: the question asks for the probability of a single armed group killing civilians; relevant considerations of terms: 1) UCDP's definition of 'one-sided violence' (government forces targeting unarmed civilians) excludes all other forms of killings (State-based violence, non-state violence). The definition and coding of 'civilians' is problematic, as the on-ground documentation of the killings have difficulty assessing if the civilians were targeted deliberately, if they were armed, and if they were a part of an organized group exercising violence. This affects the measurement of fatalities and ultimately, the probability of reaching 1000 deaths within a year highly unlikely. 2) The Early Warning Project (EWP) considers the death of at least 1000 civilians deliberately killed as mass killings. EWP mirrors Uppsala's methodology of battle-related deaths, but has its own datasets on Any Ongoing Mass Killing.

Significantly less likely than predicted by EWP. Suspect bias in reporting secondary to desired social signals and not strictly empirical evidence. Vast majority of campaigns minor civilian losses with much less than 1,000 fatalities.

Yemen is experiencing a severe humanitarian crisis, with 14.3 million people classified as being in acute need (https://news.un.org/en/story/2019/02/1032811) and several thousands of casualties (https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2019/country-chapters/yemen). However, the question brings in a lot of technicalities: fatalities have to occur in a systematic way in order to be counted in, and widespread deaths need to be provoked by specific policies. These elements make it harder for the presented scenario to be realized, and therefore I only assign a slim probability to the "yes" answer.
Yes, the western coalition (saudi royal family, united arab emirates, and the euro/white mercenaries) will kill more than 1000 people in the next year.

Conflict's will always be hard to forecast as they in nature are extremely unpredictable, even more so when armed nongovernmental groups are involved. One could argue that their reasoning is based less on logic and more on motivations and other pulling factors (push and poll), make them highly unpredictable as motivations and pulling factors could change drastically from day to day. This is one of the reasons why I have decided on a low percentage for this forecast. However, the forecast is also based on: 1. Even though the death tolls are high, accurate numbers are hard to come by, however Save the Children estimated that around 50,000 children had died on 2017, not only due to the conflict, but also the ongoing hunger crisis (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-46261983). The Human Right Watch stated in a report that as of November 2018 6,872 civilians had been murdered due to the conflict (https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2019/country-chapters/yemen). With that being said, as the Early Warning Project state in their 2018-19 Statistical Risk Assessment For Mass Killing no mass killing has occurred so far during the conflict, actually the country has not seen a mass killing since 1945 (https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/yemen). As one knows, historical data is extremely important when making a forecast, and based on the historical data, together with the capabilities of the armed groups from Yemen, I find it very unlikely that they will be able to systematically kill 1,000 or more civilians. 2. Speaking of historical data, a quick Google search (I.E. 1000 civilians killed) will show that the main results involve sophisticated militaries such as the U.S. and the UK, adding armed groups to the search will not alter the results by much, but when it does it will alter the number of casualties in the mentioned attacks, such as death tolls as low as 18. This speaks to the fact that it is very unlikely that the Yemen armed groups will beat the statistics and systematically kill a 1,000 civilians or more. 3. Being able to poll of an attack as mentioned in the question at hand takes many resources and military capabilities the Yemen armed groups are not in possession off. In the Google search mentioned in point 2, all attacks that involved 1,000 civilians casualties or more happened during airstrikes, or as mentioned with/ or with assistance of sophisticated militaries and their weapons. Even though some foreign states have been getting involved in the conflict by for example providing weapons and other military support, it is unlikely that this will help the Yemen armed groups in this case, especially considering the other points made above.

Between the beginning of the Yemeni civil war and November 2018, the totality of civilian casualities is 6872 (https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2019/country-chapters/yemen). This is indeed a terrible number, but together with the absence of singular event leading to 1000 civilian casualities (for the conflict timeline, see also https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yemeni_Civil_War_(2015%E2%80%93present) ) it shows that the event we have to forecast has not happened before. Moreover, excluding the sadly frequent casualties derived from military accidents, the events in which 1000 civilian casualties could be made are reduced to massive terrorism attacks or specific campaigns directed to the civilian population (what we could call an Uganda scenario). I would say that the kind of warfare, the overall path the war is running and the size of terrorism attacks - generally leading to not more than 250/300 casualties - lead to think to the questioned event as very unlikely, even if the Early Warning Project put a 16,1% probability for this event to happen in 2019.

The early warning project (EWP) writes that the probability of mass-casualty campaign to commence in Yemen in 2019 is 16.1%. The EWP also states that Yemen has not yet experienced such an event, though the Yemeni people has suffered greatly during the ongoing conflict. A majority of the civilian losses are due to Saudi Arabian led air strikes (https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/06/key-facts-war-yemen-160607112342462.html). Though, such fatalities do not count towards the type of systematic killing asked about in this forecast. Hence, the likelihood and effect of these attacks are not considered. The Houthi grouping too has been responsible for the deaths of civilians, however, not in the form of large-scale campaigns.

According to the EWP, there is a 16.1% chance of a civil mass killing beginning in Yemen in 2018 -2019 (ranks 6th highest among 162 countries). The percentage is decreasing compared to 2017-2018, when it was 22.3% (ranks 4th). Plus, never happened in the past to Yemen to experience mass killing. In December 2018 the two main belligerent parts (Huthi and Hadi) signed a ceasefire in Stockholm, supposed to last six months. Even if so far there has been some disagreement between the two about the control of cities like the port of al-Hudaya (claimed by the government while the rebels want it to be under the UN supervision); the ceasefire has been respected by the conflict parts, plus supported by international actors like USA, UK, Europe. This could let me forecast that the war, in its 5th year, is might finding an ending. Moreover, I believe that there would not be reasons for the Yemenites for engaging a mass civilians kill. The conflict is the consequence of a complicated and turbulent transfer of power from the autocratic regime of Saleh (Huthi side) to Hadi, during the Arab Spring. The political transition didn't bring the expected stability, but I do not think that strike the civilians would be useful to one of the two factions. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29319423 However, the consequences of the war and the massive support to Hadi side by neighbouring states as Saudi Arabia have caused difficulties to the civil population, blocking the rebel-held Red Sea city of Hudaydah, whose port is the principal lifeline for almost two thirds of Yemen's population. To struggle the Huthi rebels, Arab intentionally policy is about to beat them because of starvation, and that’s why they would be responsible of food blockage. According to UN, Thousands more civilians have died from preventable causes, including malnutrition, disease and poor health and Yemen is descending toward famine. Nevertheless, these measures are taken by the Arab government and not by the Yemenites actors, and that’s why I don’t think that any Yemenite armed group would cause the death of more than 1,000 civilians. https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29319423

Despite minor incidents nothing has changed dramatically since the last forecast (https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/world/yemen--saudis--uae-accuse-huthis-of-breaking-pullback-deal-11314978). Thus, the forecast at hand sticks to its former assessment.
I do not believe there will be a campaign to systematically kill 1000s of civilians.

While the Saudi-led coalition has led to the death of 6,000+ civilians in Yemen since the conflict started, it is unlikely that any Yemeni-based group will conduct actions that lead to civilian deaths and threaten the anti-Saudi narrative that permeated Western Media in late 2018...

Early Warning Project estimates that there is a 16.1% chance of a new mass killing beginning in Yemen in 2018 or 2019. It was 22.3% in 2017-2018. Thus there is a reduction. Moreover, this is not chance for a systematical mass killing, engage by an armed group from Yemen. EWP also demonstrates that Yemen never had a mass killing, nor any ongoing mass killing. According to the UNHCR, from 2015 to September 2018, at least 6 660 civils died. The UN said 10 000 civil casualties since one year and half. However, in Yemen, there is no reason to kill civilians, both sides seek to satiate their legitimacy and their claims. Popular support is very important, especially in civil wars. This idea of ​​popular support tends to demonstrate the impossibility of a mass killing consciously perpetrated by the Yemeni belligerents. In December 2018, a cease-fire agreement was signed in Stockholm between the belligerents with the help of the UN, which tends to demonstrate the collapse of the war. Russia, the United States, Europe and the countries of the region agree that the war must be stopped. The chances of a process of exit from the conflict in Yemen appear to be becoming clearer. This cease-fire therefore considerably reduces the chances of a return of a big spike in tension, like 2014-2015, and therefore the possibility of a deliberate campaign of mass killing. Nevertheless, indirectly, if we consider the policy chosen by the Arab coalition, the food blockade of the country, as a deliberate policy of mass killing, through famine, to struggle the Houtist partisans, and the fact that the Arab coalition includes forces loyal to the Yemeni president, then an armed group of Yemen would be possible to be considered indirectly responsible for a voluntary mass murder during this war, according to the points of view. The blockade of the country by the Arab powers has caused the "worst humanitarian crisis on the planet" according to the United Nations: 7 million people, a quarter of the population, are on the verge of starvation. Notwithstanding, for answering the question for 2019, since the case of the assassination of the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi on October 2, 2018, Mohammed Bin Salman and his coalition have lost many Western supporters, and critics have streamed about the military ways of the kingdom. It is therefore unlikely that it will continue in this form (hence the blockade), and therefore the chances of a voluntary mass killing (indirectly supported by a force in the Yemenite presence) are drastically reduced for the year 2019. Apart from a renewed hostilities and the renewal of the war, it seems very unlikely, nearly impossible, to witness a voluntary mass killing in Yemen by a Yemenite armed group.

The forecast at hand is asked to estimate the likelihood of a systematic campaign by an armed group from Yemen that kills more than 1.000 civilians in Yemen. A 10% likelihood is estimated for this event to realize. Hereby, the EWP condition has to be stressed, according to which the executing actors have to be from Yemen. The EWP explicitly excludes cases of casualties caused by foreign armed groups. For the forecast at hand this is particularly important due to the Saudi lead alliance supporting the Yemeni government. According to the research group The Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED), 6.480 civilians have been killed since 2016 as a result of 3.071 attacks that directly targeted them. Two third of them were caused by the Saudi-lead coalition, and thus have to be excluded (https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/yemen-60000-dead-armed-violence-2016-research-group-says). The same holds true for the Saudi-lead coalition’s broad restrictions on aid and essential goods to Yemen’s civil population, which could be otherwise counted in due to the amount of critically food insecure people (https://www.hrw.org/news/2017/12/07/yemen-coalition-blockade-imperils-civilians). The rest of the attacks were conducted by the Houthis (1.027 civilians), the Saudi backed government, AQAP and Isis, as well as further secessionist groups in Yemen’s south (https://www.middleeasteye.net/news/yemen-60000-dead-armed-violence-2016-research-group-says). The forecast at hand assesses the capacities of all of these actors as too limited to effectively conduct a systematic campaign to kill more than 1.000 civilians within the year. Of them, the Houthis would still be in the best position to conduct a campaign of this magnitude, in particular by means of missile attacks. However, the likelihood of the event at hand to materialize gets further decreased by the ceasefire agreed in Sweden in December that call on the government and Houthis to recall their troops from ports, as well as the latest agreement on the first phase of a withdrawal from the key city of Hodeidah (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/feb/17/yemen-and-houthi-rebels-agree-to-withdrawal-deal). The struggle about this area,“whose port is the principal lifeline for almost two thirds of Yemen's population” (https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-29319423) was the main reason for the last drastic increase in causalities after the coalition launched a major offensive. Within 4 months, civilian deaths raised by 164%, with 500 people killed in only 9 days (https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2018/sep/26/huge-spike-in-yemen-violence-as-civilian-deaths-rise-by-164-in-four-months-hodeidah). This emphasizes how fast the situation can escalate, in particular if the demilitarization of the port cities fail and serves furthermore as a justification for this forecast to stick to a 10% likelihood for a campaign by an armed group, killing more than 1.000 civilians in 2019.

At present the EWP does not recognise Yemen as a country currently experiencing mass killings by an armed group. It places Yemen in the at ‘consistently high-risk’ category — denoting a 16.1% chance of mass killings beginning in 2019, based on 2017 data. Thus far, Saudi Arabian airstrikes account for the majority of the civilian deaths (6800). Yemeni groups have not committed systematic mass killings to date, and it is unlikely that they will during 2019 given the UN-led Irani-Saudi Arabian peace deal which has, for the most part, been upheld (reuters.com, 26 Feb). It is thus considered highly unlikely that the conflict will re-escalate to a level that Yemeni forces begin systematically killing civilians.

The EWP “Early Warning Project” estimates that “there is a 16.1%, or approximately 1 in 6, chance of a new mass killing beginning in Yemen in 2018 or 2019”. I believe that the chances are lower than that. According to the EWP, Yemen has not undergone “mass killings” in the four years of conflict (https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/reports/relative-risk-of-mass-killing-onset-in-2019-results-from-a-comparison-survey). It is argued that reason to that are tribal system/culture and strategic disinterest (ushmm.org 2015). Moreover, following the murder of US-based Saudi Journalist Jamal Khashoggi, the Coalition has weakened as several European countries and the US have taken action against Saudi Arabia to express their distress e.g end of arms export, end of US aerial refuelling for the war operations in Yemen (reuters.com). In that sense, the end of the year 2018 brought new perspectives on the conflict that has entered its fifth year. For instance, a cease-fire — yet fragile — came into force in December 2018 (reuters.com) presupposing the improvement of the situation. In that sense, it is very unlikely that an armed group from Yemen engages in a campaign targeting civilians for the first time, this year.

Yemen war is essentially a proxywar between Saudi Arabia and Iran. With the start of the peace deal, brokered by the UN in december 2018, the two parties have started to come closer together. Despite many Incidents on both sides of the border, the current trajectory seems to head towards some kind of standoff rather than a continuation of fighting in which systematic killing of civilians occurs.

An average of 14 people have been killed daily over the last three years. The number of casualties range from single digits to 51 to 141 in various incidents over the years despite the air power of regional and major powers.
The middle east just does that sometimes
I believe the crowd has this more or less right, "from Yemen" being the key phrase above.
Lowered forecast - In spite of cease fire violation accusations by both sides, UN working to get more monitors into the country which could lower the probability of event.

One of the main challenges in reaching the 1000 death mark is that how do you get your hands on that many people - report from Al jazeera highlighting the numbers of prisoners of war each side has, and the fact that they have failed to reach an agreement in prisoner transfer has me raising my prediction. https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/01/yemens-war-agreement-reached-prisoner-swap-deal-jordan-190119164117438.html

Reports have been published about more religious detentions and torture by the Houthis https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/01/houthis-illegally-detaining-torturing-women-yemeni-activists-190117135833595.html Also, reports about refusal to allow food distribution as a form of recruiting (interpretation is mine) https://foreignpolicy.com/2018/12/05/united-nations-world-food-program-body-declares-famine-conditions-in-parts-of-yemen-conflict-humanitarian-crisis-middle-east-congress-trump-saudi-arabia-mohammed-bin-salman-jamal-khashoggi-pressure-en/ I increase the prob in 5 points.

Won't happen. If armed groups rise up, it'll be to fight Saudi which has already been responsible for killing thousands of Yemeni civilians. The most likely scenario would be a militia, similar to ISIS (perhaps Al Qeuda led) rising and taking control as they are seen as the counter to Saudi aggression. Needing a distraction from domestic issues, Trump orders US join Saudi in all-out bombing campaigns to target "suspected militants" which will result in tons of stories such as... "5 suspected militants killed along side 30 civilians... but we got the bad guys."

I am assuming here that "policies that knowingly result in widespread death (e.g., mass starvation, " would mean that the Houthi rebels stealing food aid and denying it to certain areas would count towards a campaign to systemically kill civilians, so am thinking of revising my estimate up on the basis of the following news reports. But these are from last year, and I don't know how much of impact the theft has actually had on the famine. ( https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2019/jan/02/aid-officials-aware-for-months-of-widespread-food-aid-theft-in-yemen , https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/01/al-jazeera-captures-evidence-food-aid-stolen-yemen-war-190103161522796.html ) I think that the trouble actually collecting the data as regards to who dies of what and where (estimates of famine deaths usually come with the proviso that they are underestimates) might mean that the actual resolution of the question is difficult.
Most incompetent warriors ever. They don't even have running water.

I am assuming that the qualifier "from Yemen" does not include the Saudi-led coalition purportedly acting in the interests of Abdrabbuh Mansur Hadi's controversial government. The Saudi-led coalition, with the support of the American government, have already killed tens and tens of thousands of Yemeni civilians as a result of the systematic imposition of blockades which have prevented desperately needed food and aid to reach Yemen's starving population.
13 December leading to a ceasefire.
I don’t believe a death of 1000 people will occur with the Yemeni government by March 31, 2019. I think rather the killing will be by Saudia Arabia which would be a military killing.
Yea...
Systematic killing of civilians is too easy to do in Yemen and policing is impossible with current world politics.
Early Warning base rate is 16.1% Genocide Watch calls it an emergency. ACLED civilian data for the last year was 867. Any objective analysis is that genocide is already happening there.
With the backing of Saudi Arabia and with the support of the US I think this is a strong probability.
Worst global tragedy will inevitably lead to further violence

https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/yemen-war-death-toll-saudi-arabia-coalition-military-assistance-uk-a8678376.html https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the-deadly-war-in-yemen-rages-on-so-why-does-the-death-toll-stand-still-/2018/08/02/e6d9ebca-9022-11e8-ae59-01880eac5f1d_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.ed36eeeeacc4
They will certainly die, but as defined in the question
the Saudi military with the assistance of the US, Britain and France have been doing this on a regular basis. only 1,000 would imply a dramatic reduction

The question is referring to policies that intentionally target civilians. None of these policies have been reported (as per my understanding) so far in Yemen. It is unclear to me if famine is part of an intentional policy (https://sites.tufts.edu/wpf/strategies-of-the-coalition-in-the-yemen-war/). I start with a 15% for that. The conflict is political, which means less likely to target civilians, and not religious or ideological. ISIS is part of the conflict, but I give a (relatively) small 1% change to be able engage in such campaign.

The question is specifically asking about non accidental civilian deaths, by groups from Yemen. The Saudi led coalition is blockading the country and is bombing food infrastructure, contributing to the famine which has killed more than 85,000 people, but this is a foreign group and therefore doesn't count in this question (as far as I can tell).
The "systematic" definition is far too narrow to encompass the vast majority of civilian deaths. I would prefer the question be for "any" civilian deaths.
